title: Crocodile Head and Ibis
section: The Late Period through the Beginning of the Roman Occupation

labels.title: 68.83.1
labels.content: In the Old Kingdom (circa 2670–2195 B.C.) silver was more valuable than gold, but this gradually changed. By the New Kingdom gold was twice as valuable as silver, and by the Ptolemaic Period it was thirteen times as valuable. This, along with the corrosiveness of silver, may explain why many of the silver sculptures known from ancient Egypt are Ptolemaic in date.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
